Richard Nixon.Action: Sits alone in a dark, silent room, silhouetted and separated from others, with a large tumbler of Scotch nearby.
Receives the tapes quietly from Haig without interaction or expression of gratitude or trust.
Sits quietly in shadow receiving tapes, appearing passive and possibly evasive.
Admits incompetence with threading the tape, shows vulnerability.
Grumbles and uses coarse language, shows frustration and abrasive tone.
Reflects on loyalty and trust in associates, expresses feelings of betrayal and victimization.
Portrays others negatively with harsh language and blames them, shows bitterness and resentment.
Expresses a sense of being misunderstood and unfairly hated, showing some emotional openness.
Admits he has difficulty threading the tape and drops it, showing a lack of skill with simple tasks under stress.
Shows physical and mental exhaustion, including sleep deprivation and reliance on sleeping pills, impairing his effectiveness.
Expresses frustration and bitterness about how events unfolded and blames others, revealing a defensive and possibly less strategic mindset in crisis.
Acknowledges Haig's concern and reflects on his own emotional guardedness and motives.
Dismisses emotional openness as 'crap' and psychoanalysis, showing reluctance to share feelings.
Expresses pride in perseverance and loyalty to country rather than emotional connection.
Refuses to show vulnerability or emotional openness, believing it would make him appear pathetic and undermine his authority.
Confidently asserts that he did not quit or withdraw from Vietnam despite pressure, implying resilience and determination.
Uses a tape recorder and listens carefully to recorded voices to gather information, demonstrating methodical and attentive behavior.
Shows signs of fatigue and irritability, briefly losing patience during conversation.
Expresses confusion and concern over break-in and potential misuse of political contributions; shows engagement with details and frustration.
Listens carefully to information and asks clarifying questions such as 'Why'd they go into O'Brien's office?' and 'Did Mitchell know?'
Expresses confusion about the break-in targets and seems to misunderstand or miss the implications of the burglars' intentions.
Calls Martha 'an idiot' and refers to others with harsh, dismissive language ('sonofabitch', 'fruitcake', 'nut').
Expresses impatience and distrust toward his associates and suspects them of ulterior motives ('these CIA guys don't miss a trick').
Dismisses serious issues with 'I don't have time for all this shit! Just handle it, Bob! Keep it out of the White House.'
Expresses incredulous surprise at Howard Hunt working for the White House, showing genuine shock.
Directs Haldeman to handle the Watergate problem and keep it out of the White House, showing delegation and crisis management.
Expresses shock and disbelief upon learning about Howard Hunt's involvement and continued White House ties, suggesting lack of prior knowledge and oversight.
Balances multiple crises and attends to Kissinger despite ongoing major scandals, demonstrating ability to multitask under pressure.
Dismisses complex issues brusquely with 'I don't have time for all this shit!', potentially ignoring details that require attention.
Appears perturbed and shaken as he processes information about illegal activities connected to his administration.
Dismisses connection to illegal break-ins with loftiness, showing detachment.
Expresses visible frustration and disgust upon learning about the Pentagon Papers and government lies.
Attempts to feed his dog despite personal and political stress.
Attempts to feed his dog to calm himself during a tense conversation, showing a moment of seeking comfort.
Dismisses the struggles expressed by others and expresses frustration with his dog for not appearing happy, showing irritability and lack of empathy.
Blames Kissinger and others for leaks and responds with anger and profanity.
Dismisses serious national security and political crises by focusing on trivial issues like the dog's behavior and blaming others instead of taking action.
Expresses frustration and anger openly, displaying a lack of control and inability to handle critical situations effectively.
Accuses colleagues of leaking to the press; cold and distrustful tone toward Kissinger and others.
Expresses desire to 'screw Ellsberg so bad' to deter leaks; endorses aggressive, ruthless tactics.
Responds coldly and dismissively to Kissinger's description of Ellsberg; shows skepticism and lack of empathy.
Rejects simplistic intellectual excuses coldly and directly, showing clarity and decisiveness.
Directs focus on stopping Ellsberg at all costs, prioritizing political damage control.
Expresses skepticism about legal actions like prosecuting the New York Times, recognizing their limited effectiveness.
Seeks creative and intimidating solutions to deter leaks, displaying strategic thinking.
Accuses and pressures close aides about internal leaks, indicating a controlling and suspicious mindset.
Implicates his own team and shows paranoia about leaks within his circle.
Ignores Kissinger's hostile look, does not escalate conflict.
Expresses frustration about leaks and desires to stop them to focus on important policy goals.
Approves creating a covert intelligence unit inside the White House.
Smiles approvingly at idea of aggressive fix for leaks.
Justifies harsh, brutal measures against leaks likening it to Nazi tactics in WWII, emphasizing ruthlessness over kindness.
States 'I don't think you can be Mr. Nice-guy anymore,' signaling rejection of warmth and friendliness in favor of severity.
Expresses deep distrust and bitterness about being socially ostracized and disparaged by elites, highlighting his own outsider status.
Focuses obsessively on dishonesty in others, emphasizing punishment of lies rather than reconciliation or understanding.
Shares a cryptic, cynical view that others 'fuck you' when they know you have something to protect, implying distrust and a defensive posture.
Recalls and applies past experience (Alger Hiss case) to current situation (Pentagon Papers) to frame the issue as about a lie, showing insight and strategic thinking.
Uses rhetorical framing ('It's the lie that gets you') to rally and persuade his team, demonstrating confident leadership.
Engages with and acknowledges key advisors (like Kissinger) while maintaining control, indicating political savvy and competence.
Commands aggressive actions against Ellsberg, aiming to destroy his reputation and privacy.
Refuses to explain his meaning about Hunt, chooses not to answer a question.
Insists on paying Howard Hunt to secure his silence regardless of legality or ethics.
Commands 'Silence!' to halt discussion, showing intolerance to questions or concerns.
Shows calculated concern about cover-up and secrecy, prioritizing self-protection over transparency.
Commands subordinates to cover up wrongdoing and manipulate intelligence agencies to obstruct justice.
Dismisses concerns about morality and justice in favor of secrecy and control.
Recognizes the strategic importance of managing enemies and preventing scandals from damaging the administration's programs.
Demonstrates awareness of political realities such as FBI resentment and international relations.
Refuses to engage in social obligations citing workload, showing focus and prioritization.
Orders a deliberate misinformation strategy to the press, instructing to 'Tell 'em anything but the goddamn truth!'
Appears anxious and physically trembling, fumbling with pills and drinking heavily under stress.
Expresses despair and self-pity with statements like 'Why don't they just fucking shoot me?'
Appears uncomfortable and robotic during debates, with a glaring demeanor.
Refuses makeup and a better suit despite looking unwell, rejecting help offered out of personal pride and discomfort with appearance-related help.
Engages continuously in campaign activities despite recent hospitalization, showing dedication and stamina.
Refuses to wear makeup for TV appearance, citing personal disdain, leading to an unpolished, fatigued appearance.
Delivers campaign speech with some factual details about geopolitical numbers and strategy.
His unwell appearance and refusal to adopt basic image-enhancing measures cause concern among aides and family, potentially impairing public perception.
Fumbles his response nervously during a debate moment, shows vulnerability.
Reacting internally with bitterness and feeling 'stolen from' after being attacked, showing frustration but no outward hostility.
Expresses genuine personal disappointment and a sense of betrayal by Kennedy, recalling their past close relationship ('like brothers').
Focuses on the bitterness of electoral defeat and accusations of cheating, building rage rather than conciliatory or forgiving behavior.
Considers calling for a recount and looks into election fraud claims with his team.
Frustrated and overwhelmed by the election loss, expresses disbelief and personal resentment.
Acknowledges political realities and practical constraints voiced by his aides about contesting the election.
Focuses on perceived personal slights and narrative of cheating rather than immediate strategic action.
Expresses bitterness and resentment about his background and perceived unfair treatment, but also shows vulnerability and a desire to be understood.
Suppresses his visible pain and exits quietly after hearing counsel to accept defeat.
Controls his reaction despite deep personal pain and disappointment, then exits the room quietly.
Expresses bitterness and obsession over perceived unfairness and personal grievances.
Hesitates before knocking on the door in subdued morning light, showing moments of doubt or uncertainty.
Allows Pat to touch him and shares intimate emotions about loss and family, showing vulnerability and seeking comfort.
Expresses frustration and bitterness about losing and the pressures of public life but remains open to Pat's counsel and concern.
Mentions his father's honesty and misses him deeply, revealing sincere emotional depth and humility.
Considers leaving politics after a significant loss, reflecting on personal and family costs.
Admits emotional vulnerability and doubts his past and future success.
Whispers to his brother, tries to avoid mother's reprimand, shows fear of her reaction.
Obediently listens to his mother, appears gloomy and unsmiling in her presence.
Interacts with family members with subtle concern and attempts at gentle communication.
Richard listens carefully to his brother and mother, shows awareness of social cues (e.g., worries about mother's reaction) and obeys mother quietly and attentively.
Richard is terrified and buries his face in his hands, showing nervousness and lack of confidence in a social situation.
Lies to his mother about smoking, then begs forgiveness and promises never to do it again, showing vulnerability.
Describes himself to his mother as 'your faithful dog,' indicating loyalty and a desire for approval and closeness.
Attempts to say grace nervously, trying to please family.
Follows family ritual and shows respect to mother by agreeing to pray.
Remembers his parents' struggle and resilience, tries to emulate their perseverance.
Demonstrates personal grit and toughness by repeatedly returning to play football despite physical punishment.
Despite being physically outmatched and playing as a substitute with a cheap uniform, Nixon repeatedly gets up after painful hits and continues to play with determination and pluck.
Remembers his father's lifelong struggle and uses it as motivation to persevere when things do not go his way.
Blames external factors (Fidel Castro) for his defeat and expresses bitterness openly.
Dismisses Pat's attempt at empathy and support, responding with sarcasm and bitterness.
Relies on cynical worldview that people vote out of fear, showing distrust and lack of faith in others.
Continues playing music and tries to engage Pat by suggesting to listen to a victory speech despite tension.
Responds to Pat's declaration of wanting a divorce with confusion and concern about the family.
Appears awkward and somewhat disconnected from Pat’s emotional state.
Rejects Pat's desire for divorce by emphasizing political identity over personal life.
Urges Pat not to give up on their relationship, expresses deep commitment and tenderness.
Seeks physical closeness and emotional connection, asking Pat to look at him and respond.
Recognizes and addresses the emotional withdrawal of Pat, sees the situation clearly and tries to keep their relationship together by appealing to their shared history and bond.
Attempts to gently reconnect physically and emotionally, uses tender language to reassure Pat and negotiate the future of their marriage effectively.
Promises Pat he will never run again to prevent divorce.
Defends Governor Brown's patriotism publicly despite political rivalry.
Criticizes the press but asks them to occasionally report his true words.
Decides not to run again and promises to quit, showing resolve and taking responsibility.
Breaks away from aides' advice and abruptly addresses the press himself, taking control of the narrative.
Uses the press conference to defend opponents and articulate his own position clearly and confidently.
Delivers his last press conference with a tone of finality and bitterness, implying alienation and lack of connection with others.
Wages aggressive campaigns by associating opponents with Communism and treating politics as war, ruining enemies rather than engaging as rivals.
Wins his first term in the House by associating his liberal opponent with Communism, a strategic move during post-war Red Scare politics.
Approaches politics as war, treats opponents as enemies and aims to ruin them, demonstrating a ruthless and calculated political strategy.
Delivers a final press conference and then vanishes amidst chaos, signaling a dramatic and possibly self-defeating exit.
Conducts a vicious campaign using smear tactics and aggressive attacks against opponents.
Promises to expose and drive out ‘crooks and Communists’ undermining the country.
Questioning witnesses aggressively about communist propaganda in Hollywood, demonstrating investigatory skill and confidence.
Using the discovery of the microfilm in the pumpkin patch as a key piece of evidence and deftly playing to the cameras, showing strategic awareness and political skill.

The microfilm evidence later revealed to be innocuous and not classified, indicating a potential failure to verify the importance or authenticity before publicizing, reflecting poor judgment or overreach.
Keeps the family dog 'Checkers' because the kids love it and insists on keeping it.
Televised Checkers speech viewed by 58 million people, described as a huge success.
Portrayed negatively by opponents as untrustworthy, manipulative, and deceitful.
Openly admits early career rejections and obstacles, showing self-awareness about challenges like not fitting the mold for prestigious law firms and being turned down by the FBI.
Expresses emotional anguish over his daughter's distress and personal setbacks, revealing vulnerability but also ongoing engagement with personal and career struggles.
Engages strategically in social settings by tracking the movement of an important political figure (Nelson Rockefeller), indicating tactical awareness and networking acumen.
Laughs along with Martha's joke and tries to explain the photo situation to others.
Mocks Martha's drunkenness with a harsh comment about her being 'smashed' and complains that Pat can't stand her.
Calls AP to correct misleading information about his image, demonstrating awareness and proactive engagement with his public perception.
Dismisses criticism of his image with sarcasm, showing defensive behavior but not necessarily a lack of competence.
Engages in banter about Martha's drunkenness, showing casual and candid behavior but not directly related to competence.
Acknowledges Rockefeller's new wife with a polite greeting and compliment.
Cuts off Rockefeller's apology quickly, showing limited tolerance for apologies.
Laughs at the idea that the 'son of a grocer can become president,' showing a relatable and inclusive attitude.
Responds to Rockefeller's physical affection by not reciprocating, indicating discomfort with touch.
Engages in witty and confident conversation, demonstrates social skill and quick repartee.
Admits to losing a Supreme Court case but frames it positively by focusing on experience and current activities like writing a book.
Implicitly acknowledges financial success but also self-imposes moral constraints, showing self-awareness.
Laughs awkwardly and makes a pointed comment about voters reacting to Rockefeller's divorce.
Clutches Rockefeller's hand and receives a friendly squeeze before releasing it.
Responds cordially to introduction of Kissinger and compliments Rockefeller's book.
Plans to write a book called 'Six Crises' showcasing his handling of difficult political events, indicating self-awareness and confidence in his experience.
Engages in witty, somewhat confrontational banter with Rockefeller about political crises and personal vulnerabilities, showing social skill but also a hint of defensiveness.
Laughs awkwardly when challenged by Rockefeller on the number of crises, revealing a slight discomfort or insecurity.
Demonstrates knowledge of political figures, events, and nuances in conversation with Rockefeller, showing intelligence and political savvy.
Engages intellectually with Kissinger and Rockefeller, showing awareness of political dynamics.
Criticizes Rockefeller’s chances scathingly, showing insight into political prospects.
Displays seething anger and bitterness openly at the party.
Participates in a harsh, dismissive conversation with Mitchell, including use of crude language.
Expresses deep personal pain and longing for social connection and 'making love to the people,' shows vulnerability about missing the arena of public life.
Feels mentally and physically dead without public engagement, conveys sincere emotional distress.
Poses for photographs and shakes hands with autograph seekers while looking uncomfortable.
Declines to fully engage with the party and tries to excuse himself to catch an early plane, showing some self-control and focus.
Attempts to downplay his status by saying he is 'just a New York lawyer now,' possibly showing a strategic modesty or an underestimation of his influence.
Smiles awkwardly and passively responds to the social situation, showing some discomfort and lack of ease in social maneuvering.
Shows pictures of his kids to Sandy and attempts to make personal conversation.
Responds awkwardly to Jack Jones and sticks to business talk despite social setting.
Initiates a straightforward business discussion during a social setting, showing focus and intent to handle matters efficiently.
Appears somewhat awkward and reserved in social interactions, smiling awkwardly and responding hesitantly to suggestive situations.
Attempts to build rapport by showing personal photos and making conversational remarks, demonstrating social skill and emotional intelligence.
Swallows hard, blushes, and shows discomfort with intimacy but engages in gentle conversation asking Sandy about her likes and family.
Internally flashes an image of himself as beastlike, offensive, unworthy upon Sandy's affectionate gesture.
Looks around desperately searching for Trini, showing some insecurity and social awkwardness.
Sweats, blushes, and stammers uncomfortably during an intimate conversation, showing social awkwardness and lack of confidence.
Attempts to engage by asking questions about Sandy's preferences, showing effort to connect despite awkwardness.
Listens and responds respectfully to Sandy's statements, demonstrating basic conversational skill.
Quickly looks around desperately for Trini, indicating insecurity or discomfort in social situation.
Affirms agreement with Jones on dangerous political times with concise, confident acknowledgement ('Agreed').
Politely deflects Cuban patriots' concerns, appreciates their sentiments but asserts limits to his influence.
Mentions promise to his wife and decision to leave politics, indicating personal loyalty and sincerity.
Displays skepticism and distrust toward others (subconscious reptilian image of Cuban), signaling coldness or wariness.
Rejects opportunities to run again, insists on 'out of politics' despite pressure and offers of money.
Acknowledges his efforts to influence policy (tried to get Kennedy to go into Cuba) but accepts reality and limits of his control.
Dismisses the possibility of beating Kennedy in 1964 despite large financial backing, showing realism and political calculation.
Appears to avoid engagement with the Cuban group's offer and ultimately states he is out of politics, despite clear pressure and opportunity.
Shakes Jones's hand before departing.
Refers to his country as 'not available' when called upon, showing a distancing or reluctance.
Accepts that Bobby Kennedy doesn't want him at the funeral and does not try to force his presence; acknowledges the estrangement sincerely.
Reflects quietly and with evident pain on past family suffering (his younger brother Arthur's medical ordeal) but cannot bear to intervene during the crisis as a child.
Sits close by, squeezing Arthur's hand, showing concern for his ill son.
Feels awkward and stutters when asked by Arthur to say a prayer, indicating discomfort but sincerity.
Watches devastated as Arthur slips into a coma, revealing deep emotional pain and attachment.
Throws arms around his mother in a moment of seeking comfort, showing vulnerability and need for connection.
Mother responds harshly and angrily, snapping him back, which may indicate he is met with coldness, but Richard does not retaliate or respond negatively.
Shows detached and absorbed behavior when Pat asks if he will call, indicating emotional distance.
Chooses to go 'through Lyndon' to be invited, implying a passive or indirect approach rather than direct connection.
Quietly decides to try to go through Lyndon Johnson to be invited, rather than immediately calling directly.
Appearing lost in memory and absent during Pat's questioning about calling, showing hesitation or indecision.
Follows Pat when she walks away cold, trying to engage her.
Uses affectionate nickname 'Buddy' for Pat and takes her hand.
Encourages and reassures Pat about her importance and their shared mission.
Mentions using 'old Nixon charm' on Pat in a somewhat calculated way.
Expresses love and admiration for Pat, hugs her sincerely, shows vulnerability and earnestness in intimate moment.
Engages with campaign audience on TV, avoids attacking opponent's patriotism directly.
Responds courteously to the Black Man with 'Yes, sir!'
Career built on smearing people as Communists and stirring division
Appears as a mouthpiece for a hidden agenda, avoiding real dialogue
Prepared to engage in a televised campaign, attempts to maintain control in a difficult live-TV situation.
Allowing a hostile participant to freely criticize him on live television without cutting off or controlling the narrative, causing distress among his aides.
Acknowledges national divisions and appeals for unity by referencing Abraham Lincoln and the silent majority, addressing a little girl with a heartfelt message.
Deflects accusation from the Black Man by blaming the Democrats and labels violent protesters negatively, avoiding genuine engagement with the concerns raised.
Expresses a desire to bring the country together and connects to his humble origins sincerely.
Repeatedly emphasizes his modest upbringing to build rapport.
Delivers a rallying call to 'bring us together,' confidently addressing the audience and capturing their enthusiasm.
Uses personal background stories in his speech to connect with his audience, demonstrating calculated communication skills.
Despite Hoover's dismissive interruptions and mimicking, Nixon maintains his assertive narrative through voiceover, showing resilience and control.
Is described as on his way up by Roselli, indicating rising influence and recognition.
Unaware of Hoover's resentment and need to manipulate him, showing lack of insight into important relationships.
Waves to the crowd while making his way down the aisle, greeting Edgar and others warmly.
Looks sick and startled upon hearing that Johnny Roselli, a potentially disreputable figure, is nearby; denies knowing him.
Nixon looks sick upon hearing the mention of Johnny Roselli, and denies knowing him despite implications; fails to address or manage the potentially damaging association proactively.
Engages briefly and politely with Hoover and others while maintaining a presence in a tense social/political situation.
Waves to patrons of the racetrack in a friendly manner.
Speaks harshly and insultingly about political opponents, using crude language and vowing to fight dirty.
Seeks support from Hoover and Tolson for aggressive, underhanded tactics.
Demonstrates political savvy by recognizing and anticipating challenges from opponents like the Kennedy brothers, showing a realistic and strategic mindset.
Expresses willingness to employ dirty tactics and leverage potentially unethical information to fight political opponents.
Seeks and secures support from powerful figures like Hoover and the FBI, indicating resourcefulness and political networking.
Feels uncomfortable and disturbed by Hoover's pessimistic and hostile comments, showing some internal sensitivity.
Discusses covert operations and support of ruthless actions (Track 2) to remove foreign leaders, indicating willingness to endorse morally questionable measures.
Acknowledges his involvement with mob contacts and CIA operatives in assassination attempts with a tone of worry about what they might know.
Did not tell Kennedy about Track 2 to deny him credit, leading to personal bitterness and hurt.
Expresses deep hurt at being insulted by Kennedy, revealing vulnerability.
Understands the secrecy and complexity of Track 2 and navigates CIA and political networks skillfully.
Deliberately withholds important information from President Kennedy to prevent him from getting credit.
Demonstrates awareness of powerful figures like Hoover's manipulative tactics and plans accordingly.
Does not confront or manage the fallout of the Track 2 operation effectively, which escalates tensions and mistrust.
Hurries out to hold and comfort his dying brother Harold during a severe coughing fit, wiping his mouth.
Muses darkly on death clearing his path to the presidency, reflecting on victims as 'bodies' paving his way.
Takes a slug of Scotch, rubs the bridge of his nose, looks up at Lincoln portrait, reflects quietly about death and leadership.
Hurries out to help his seriously ill brother, holds him through a coughing fit, wipes his mouth carefully.
Feels helpless and horrified at the prospect of moving forward after his brother's death, showing emotional struggle and hesitation.
Stiffly asks Harold if he will quit on him, indicating clinging to support but also uncertainty and lack of confidence.
Sits staring into the fire, unable to accept the gift of law school, expressing bitterness and emotional turmoil.
Despite emotional difficulty, is confronted by his mother urging him to accept responsibility and strength, implying potential or expectation of competence.
Looks down at someone in the audience, points, smiles, waves; puts arm around Pat and shares a private, affectionate moment with her.
Addresses delegates pledging to restore law and order, promises commitment to truth and a new voice representing the silent majority.
Addresses a diverse silent majority including white, black, Mexican, and Italian Americans, acknowledging their love for America and anger rooted in care rather than hate.
Frames opposition groups and government activists in a hostile way, suggesting distrust and portraying them as threats ('professional welfareists', 'lying in wait').
Delivers a compelling speech appealing to the 'silent majority,' effectively rallying diverse demographic groups and framing complex social unrest in a clear, relatable manner.
Uses strong, confident rhetoric that resonates with his audience and asserts control over the narrative during a time of national crisis.
Advocates for personal responsibility and self-discipline, emphasizing that dependency weakens individuals.
Affirms freedom of choice in housing, education, and jobs as a right for every American.
Rejects forced integration in housing or education despite acknowledging legal segregation is wrong, citing limits of law based on public support.
Supports reform to improve healthcare fairness and availability to all people.
Calls for a new feeling of responsibility and self-discipline in America, advocates renewal of state and local government, and complete reform of federal government with a clear, confident plan.
Acknowledges limits of law enforcement in social issues, recognizing that laws cannot exceed public support, showing pragmatic understanding.
Proposes cutting the defense budget and reducing forces in Europe while improving domestic programs, showing strategic prioritization.
Asserts that forced integration of housing or education is wrong, reflecting controversial or potentially divisive stance rather than pragmatic problem-solving.
Expresses anger and frustration during war strategy discussion, rejects cautious advice, demands bold military action.
Interrupts Kissinger to dismiss staff opinions, insists on his own view unapologetically.
Expresses willingness to use severe military force, including assassinations, with enthusiasm.
Derides State Department officials as 'jerks' for opposing bold military actions.
Uses aggressive, crude language ('hit 'em where it hurts -- right in the nuts') indicating harshness, intimidation rather than friendliness.
Interrupts Kissinger to demand his personal opinion rather than staff consensus, demonstrating confidence and assertiveness.
Advocates for bold military action and 'taking the war to them,' showing strategic decisiveness.
Compares boldness to historic figures to justify aggressive tactics, indicating strategic framing ability.
Supports escalation of the war into Cambodia despite risks, showing willingness to make tough decisions.
Appears to endorse ruthless actions such as more assassinations and killings, reflecting a possibly reckless or morally questionable approach.
Expresses understanding and empathy toward scared young soldiers doing their duty.
Praises a suffering POW publicly and acknowledges his greatness, sharing a moment with families and military personnel.
Calls protesting students 'bums' and suggests physical punishment for them.
Expresses shock and concern upon learning students were shot and killed.
Dismisses student protesters as 'bums' and suggests corporal punishment, showing poor judgment and insensitivity to a volatile situation.
Responds grimly and seeks factual updates immediately after the Kent State shootings, indicating situational awareness and control.
Expresses frustration with media coverage but clearly understands the political damage being done, reflecting political awareness and strategic thinking.
Dismisses concerns about the nature of the student protests and insists on portraying them as anarchy and revolution, showing rigidity and lack of tolerance.
Insists on not losing the war at all costs, motivated by pride and fear of failure rather than consideration for others.
Expresses frustration that even his own men do not understand his perspective, indicating a possible emotional isolation and lack of empathy.
Frames the Communist enemy in cold, pragmatic terms and advocates for unpredictability and bluffing as strategy, reflecting a tough and impersonal approach rather than warmth or sincerity.
Dismisses concerns of reporters and grieving mothers as 'simple-minded' and unlikely to understand complex geopolitics.
Expresses confidence and determination in pursuing triangular diplomacy to strategically negotiate with China and the Soviets.
Explains the complex strategy of triangular diplomacy involving China, the Soviets, and Vietnam with understanding of geopolitics and long-term benefits.
Acknowledges the difficulty of explaining complex geopolitical strategy to the public and press, showing awareness of communication challenges.
Dismissive attitude toward press and public understanding of sensitive issues, suggesting a potential underestimation of communication importance.
Demonstrates confidence in his political risk-taking and views risk as necessary for achieving heroic and historical impact.
Claims his strong anti-Communist credentials justify bold moves like recognizing China, showing strategic self-awareness.
Keeps a major diplomatic initiative secret from his own State Department, showing distrust and manipulation.
Dismisses concerns and mocks others (example: cackling at the secrecy, angering subordinates), showing a lack of sincerity and tolerance.
Protects Hoover from repercussions to prevent backlash, indicating self-serving mistrust rather than goodwill.
Keeps critical plans secret from even his own State Department to pull off a major diplomatic coup.
Sees through media and public relations challenges and looks to control narrative ('Money. Follow the money.').
Refuses to remove Hoover despite recognizing him as ineffective, out of fear of exposure from Hoover’s secret files.
Shows frustration with the CIA for lack of actionable intelligence and demands better performance.
Clings to Cold War era thinking (Chambers, Hiss comparisons) despite contemporaries urging a more nuanced approach, indicating possible intellectual rigidity.
Expresses heartbreak over Harold's death and reflects on childhood slights and struggles with personal vulnerability.
Shrugs off a friend's comforting touch and admits he cannot offer condolences sincerely.
Reflects on how intelligence and deep anger can drive a person to change their circumstances through excellence and gut performance.
Acknowledges the need to offer condolences but states 'But Nixon can't,' implying an internal barrier or inability to act with empathy.
Shrugs off advice and walks away into the shadows, avoiding direct emotional engagement.
Mocks and belittles Vice President Agnew, calls him an 'insurance policy' and laughs at his troubles.
Jokes crudely and with impatience towards subordinates and staff.
Appropriately delegates and recognizes Agnew's value as an 'insurance policy' despite Agnew's unpopularity, showing strategic awareness.
Dismisses Agnew's requests and mocks him, using humor to deflect criticism, indicating confidence in managing political optics.
Shows impatience and command presence when the CIA Director is late, indicating decisiveness and control in a crisis setting.
Insists on a private conversation, shows impatience.
Greets Cushman with a casual question about the job.
Uses threatening language about replacing Helms.
Says 'I own the fucking casino' indicating a controlling attitude.
Jokingly responds to Helms's greeting with 'My friends call me Mister President.'
Dismisses and disregards congressional oversight with harsh language.
Displays impatience and frustration demanding results and secrecy regarding leaks.
Engages in a direct and stern manner with Helms to emphasize authority.
Paces his office, clearly focused on concerns about student funding and intelligence leaks, shows detailed knowledge of intelligence agency behavior and is assertive in demanding results.
Dismisses congressional oversight entirely, potentially undermining legitimacy and checks on power.
Demonstrates strategic awareness by requesting original signed papers from his vice presidency, showing foresight and control over sensitive information.
Shows discomfort and embarrassment when confronted about covert operations, tries to deflect scrutiny.
Insists on securing documents exclusively for himself, indicating secrecy and distrust.
Reassures Helms that the CIA agency is secure and promises reasonable funding increases, showing some level of cooperation and trustworthiness.
Asserts control over the Special Operations Group and negotiates with Helms about CIA activities and funding confidently.
Shows discomfort and embarrassment when confronted with the lack of documentation about covert operations.
Assures Helms he will continue as DCI and praises his job as magnificent.
Responds coldly to Helms about spying in the White House.
Engages in a tense discussion about intelligence and policy, appearing guarded and controlling.
Affirms continuation of Helms as DCI, praising his job well done, showing confidence in capable leadership.
Acknowledges sensitive intelligence about Soviet submarine in Cuba and plans to lodge a formal protest, but appears to underestimate seriousness per Helms’s warning.
Shows tension and surprise at Helms’s inside knowledge about Kissinger, suggesting a gap in Nixon’s own intelligence awareness.
Confronts Helms about potential spying in the White House, demonstrating suspicion but possibly indicating distrust or internal discord that may hamper effective governance.
Declares CIA has no policy except what he dictates, indicating desire for control but perhaps revealing a micromanaging tendency that questions delegation skill.
Expresses sorrow over Kennedy's death and reflects on mortality and evil.
Dismisses appreciation of flowers due to personal trauma, showing limited emotional openness.
Coldly rationalizes geopolitical sacrifices (e.g., Cuba as a 'small price to pay').
Decides to pursue opening negotiations with China to separate China from Russia and create a new balance of power, showing strategic thinking and long-term planning.
Displays hesitation and emotional distraction upon being reminded of Kennedy's assassination and his own mortality, indicating vulnerability under pressure.
Laughs and mocks colleagues on phone, uses demeaning language ('little closet fairy') targeting Hoover.
In high spirits, joking and boasting about political maneuvering with close contacts.
Engages with Pat on casual terms but hardly notices her comment, showing emotional disengagement.
Confidently jokes and boasts on the phone about outmaneuvering opponents and controlling power dynamics.
Displays high spirits and laughter after a social event, showing ease in social and political maneuvering contexts.
Hardly notices wife's comment about aging, focused instead on his aggressive political stance and decision-making.
Allows Pat to approach and nuzzle him, responds with concern about her being okay and suspects drink on her breath.
Rejects Pat's invitation to go with him to Key Biscayne, citing need to relax and avoids intimacy.
Engages briefly in a nostalgic but dismissive exchange about past affection with Pat, showing slight embarrassment and discomfort.
Initiates a focused plan to address the energy issue and manage the budget firmly.
Hangs up awkwardly on the phone, shows hesitation when Pat proposes joining him.
Reacts with embarrassment and discomfort to Pat's emotional approach, signaling inner tension.
Expresses paranoia and hostility toward others, uses harsh language about opponents, shows reluctance to share true feelings even with Pat
Addresses Pat intimately as 'Buddy', apologizes softly at the end, reveals vulnerability about pressure and legacy
Engages Manolo in personal conversation, asks about his feelings and misses Cuba, shows some concern for Manolo's well-being.
Questions why people hate him, revealing insecurity and a desire for acceptance.
Dismisses desire to be loved by the public, distancing himself from Jack Kennedy, suggesting defensiveness.
Reflects deeply on public opinion and his own legacy, showing self-awareness but also vulnerability.
Struggles to clearly articulate what he wants from Manolo, indicating some hesitation or lack of decisiveness.
Engages in a nuanced personal conversation, showing emotional intelligence and an ability to connect on a human level.
Tells the boy to go back to sleep gently after accidentally stepping on his sleeping bag.
Initiates conversation politely and attempts small talk about football with students despite tension.
Laughs nervously about being used as a tackling dummy, showing some self-deprecation.
Navigates cautiously through a challenging environment, engaging directly and confidently with students despite hostility.
Attempts to make casual conversation with students by referencing football and personal experiences, but laughs nervously, indicating some discomfort in the situation.
Admits that many think he is a 'real SOB' but expresses understanding of their feelings and desire for peace.
Reflects sincerely on his family background and moral convictions, shares personal prayer in the Lincoln Room.
Acknowledges the spiritual hunger behind social issues and shows empathy by mentioning his mother's kindness to hobos.
Uses somewhat formal and distant language about war and peace (e.g., 'you can't have peace without a price').
Does not directly address or respond emotionally to students' poignant challenges about dying in the war.
Acknowledges the death of soldiers including his own wartime experience, expresses attempts to end the war and reduce the military budget.
Hesitates and struggles to answer when confronted with the moral futility and systemic constraints of the Vietnam War.
Insists on the importance of American credibility and his belief in controlling the system despite others’ cynicism.
Acknowledges progress made by withdrawing troops and cutting military budget, expresses understanding of complexity of the situation.
Hesitates and is momentarily out of answers when confronted with the argument that the war continues because of the system, showing vulnerability.
Asserts belief that he can understand and control the system despite challenges, showing confidence and grasp of political realities.
Waves absently to protestors as he is herded away, showing a distant acknowledgment but no engagement.
Tells everyone not to forget their relationship with their Maker and to be on God's side, which may come off as sincere advice but alienates the protestors.
Expresses respect for a young woman who understood the 'Beast,' showing some openness to others' perspectives.
Reflects on a young protester's understanding of complex political forces, showing humility and an ability to recognize insight outside himself.
Allows himself to be herded by security and waves absently to protestors instead of engaging, which could be seen as a lack of assertive control in a tense situation.
Muses about protestors, questions if they have a point, shows momentary doubt.
Dismisses protestors as 'little bastards' trying to ruin his daughter's wedding, uses harsh language.
Calmly assesses the scale and persistence of protests, reflects on government stability, and discusses intelligence leaks frankly with Hoover.
Laughs off protesters' disruptive actions as mere nuisances, showing confidence and dismissiveness toward opposition.
Expresses frustration openly about inability to keep secrets in government, indicating awareness but possibly lack of effective control.
Engages in strategic conversation with Hoover about counterintelligence and political rivals, showing political savvy and tactical thinking.
Engages Hoover in a strategic discussion about leaks and tapes, shows awareness of potential threats to himself.
Appears stunned and flustered when Hoover suggests Kissinger as a leaker, fusses with bow tie signaling discomfort.
Attempts to assert control over the narrative by referencing Churchill’s advice about writing one’s own history.
Expresses worry about the consequences ('don't let it come back to haunt me'), revealing concern about risks despite attempts to manage situation.
Dances happily with his daughter at her wedding, expresses pride sincerely.
Shows intense anger and issues threats to prosecute leakers aggressively.
Dances happily with his daughter during a White House event, showing personal warmth and pride.
Suddenly erupts into the Cabinet room with focused fury, slamming the New York Times down to emphasize the seriousness of leaks.
Threatens to prosecute Ellsberg and anyone who leaks information, asserting strong control and decisiveness over government leaks.
Uses a severe, intimidating tone warning his Cabinet members about the end of permissiveness and upcoming strict discipline.
During the social event, seems focused on family and managing appearances rather than political or strategic issues.
Demonizes political opponents as traitors, employs harsh and threatening language, orders strict control over communication with the press.
Demonstrates awareness of internal threats and leakers, showing knowledge from experience dealing with traitors.
Implements strict media control by centralizing press communications through Haldeman, indicating strategic thinking to manage public information.
Uses aggressive, threatening rhetoric to motivate and intimidate his Cabinet, which may inspire fear but risks alienating colleagues, showing forcefulness but potential misjudgment.
Beams and compliments Mao Tse-Tung's appearance during diplomatic meeting.
Narrates about breaking into psychiatrist's office to obtain Ellsberg's file, expressing pride in changing the world.
Oversees covert operations such as the break-in at Dr. Lewis J. Fielding's office targeting Daniel Ellsberg, showing strategic planning and execution of secret intelligence actions.
Engages in high-stakes diplomacy by visiting Mao Tse-Tung in Beijing during a historic moment, demonstrating confident statesmanship and risk-taking in foreign policy.
Responds to Mao's compliment with self-effacing humor: 'I was the lesser of two evils.'
Engages in diplomatic conversation with Mao, maintaining composure despite provocative statements.
Responds to criticism of brutal bombing with a firm stance, showing little public remorse or empathy.
Shares a private moment of reflection with Pat, showing humor and a recognition of changing perspectives about Mao.
Shares a quiet, sincere moment with Pat, smiles and squeezes her hand when she expresses pride.
Makes cynical, dismissive statements about ethnic groups (Jews and Negros) and their political value.
Successfully negotiates a strategic advantage in the SALT treaty talks, shifting the balance of power and gaining a coup against the Russians.
Shows awareness of the political pitfalls and media backlash he will face despite the diplomatic success, indicating a realistic and strategic understanding.
Dismisses significant voter groups (Jews and African Americans) as not electorally valuable, showing a flawed and possibly shortsighted political calculation.
Acknowledges the need to gain support against Wallace's third party to avoid helping McGovern.
Engages in candid, pragmatic conversation with Jones about the realities of war, social attitudes, and economic changes.
Clearly explains the political stakes to Jones, demonstrating awareness of third-party impact and seeking support.
Engages in a reasoned discussion about the changing political and global landscape, showing strategic understanding of domestic and international challenges.
Cuts off the servant bringing coffee, no one allowed to get close to him.
Makes a sarcastic joke about food being free if you're the president, causing nervous laughter.
Jovially says he will get rid of Allende, showing political ruthlessness but no warmth.
Defends Kissinger, calling him tougher than himself, shows loyalty to associates.
Allows Jones to speak despite Haldeman's attempt to cut him off.
Responds bluntly and without compassion to Jones’ grievances, refuses personal connection.
Shows clear decisiveness and strategic intent by stating 'We're gonna get rid of Allende -- just as fast as we can.'
Demonstrates political savvy by defending Kissinger as 'misunderstood' and emphasizing his toughness, showing awareness of internal dynamics.
Uses humor ('Free, if you're the president') to ease tension, reflecting some social skill but not necessarily competence in policy.
Fails to address serious concerns about domestic economic and social issues raised by Jones, appears somewhat dismissive or detached.
Allows an uncomfortable silence after sensitive remarks without attempting to defuse tension or redirect the conversation.
Moves aggressively into Jones's face, uses confrontational language, and implies threats under the guise of presidential authority.
Acknowledges a major achievement of his administration (pulling out of Vietnam without a right wing revolt) in a matter-of-fact way.
Does not express any happiness or excitement upon hearing the Vietnamese accepted the peace proposal, despite others' enthusiasm.
Shows cold and narrowing expression upon hearing accusations about Kissinger leaking information.
Reflects strategically on major achievements like pulling out of Vietnam without provoking a right wing revolt.
Shows an understanding of political realities, recognizing that even the presidency may no longer protect him from current threats.
Does not outwardly celebrate the peace deal but contemplates the significance quietly, indicating controlled and measured response.
Quickly shifts to a more serious, cold expression upon hearing of the FBI report on Kissinger leaking, showing alertness and suspicion.
Experiences built-up rage and paranoia, shows distrust and a harsh defensive stance toward subordinates and press.
Chooses not to fire a problematic staff member to avoid public fallout, showing a pragmatic restraint.
Expresses lethal intent to invade privacy and intimidate a staff member by tapping phones to control information.
Responds coldly and with hostility to colleagues, shows little tolerance or friendly openness.
Remains calm enough to strategically decide against firing an internal adversary to avoid public backlash and preserve appearances.
Orders wiretaps and surveillance on a staff member to control leaks and information flow.
Exhibits paranoia and rage, showing a dark, conflicted inner state.
Reacting emotionally with built-up rage and bitterness rather than applying objective reasoning.
Refers disparagingly to reporters ('Who the fuck are they?'), pushes to revoke Post's television license.
Mutters relieved praise to John Dean ('Good man, John, good man.') after hearing FBI reports.
Snaps at reporters and refuses to answer serious accusations.
Gets overwhelmed by questions, reacts with anger by hurling an ashtray.
Pushes Ziegler toward reporters in frustration, showing little concern for others' feelings.
Storms into office furious, hurls ashtray, uses angry and disparaging language about opponents and media.
Defends own achievements sincerely and expresses frustration about being unfairly treated.
Dismisses concerns about others' reputations and focuses on political survival with cold pragmatism.
Warns about consequences of 'housecleaning' implying awareness of damage but resists transparency.
Analyzes the political situation critically, identifies the short-sightedness of others, and shows awareness of the consequences of housecleaning in his administration.
Avoids taking decisive action to clean up his administration despite knowing the government is paralyzed and risks further exposure.
Engages in veiled threats and cryptic responses, revealing an ability to intimidate or control the conversation.
Shows reluctance to confront internal problems openly, fearing exposure and damage, leading to inaction.
Confronts Kissinger directly and asserts control, making clear the stakes and his authority.
Reacts to threats and crises decisively, ordering payment promptly to Hunt despite the danger.
Laughs maniacally and uses crude expressions, creating a tense, unstable atmosphere.
Shows understanding of the need to control leaks and intimidate subordinates effectively.
Relies on others (Haldeman) for ideas on handling problems like Helms, showing some delegation but unclear strategic initiative.
Stares silently and is distracted during a serious discussion, showing reluctance to engage openly.
Considers political favors and financial contributions in deciding ambassadorship assignments, prioritizing money and deals over sincerity or fairness.
Latches onto Dean's idea of executive clemency as a solution and supports it quickly.
Expresses frustration and uncertainty aloud about the situation and its escalation.
Considers political realities and opposition from allies (Lyndon Johnson), showing awareness of political constraints.
Seemingly resigned and doubtful to the point of visible distress (ashen face), indicating stress and possible wavering confidence.
Commands his aides to testify by claiming executive privilege and stonewalling, attempting a defensive legal strategy.
Admits they are covering up and acknowledges the personal cost and tiredness from the situation.
Refuses to allow aides to testify, insisting on stonewalling and using executive privilege.
Expresses hesitation and emotional discomfort about sacrificing Mitchell, whom he regards as family.
Insists on claiming executive privilege and stonewalling testimony despite team concerns about the appearance of a cover-up.
Admits openly that they are covering up for petty, stupid things, showing a lack of strategic thinking.
Recognizes that when he lies, nobody believes him, indicating self-awareness but also ineffectiveness in persuasion.
Is stunned and visibly worn out when presented with the need to sacrifice Mitchell, showing emotional fatigue and potential indecisiveness.
Demonstrates some understanding of political realities through internal conflict and recognition of game rules ('sometimes you have to punt').
Described as engaging in ruthless, secretive actions causing harm and constitutional damage, driven by personal grudges.
Refuses to admit wrongdoing or apologize, maintaining a figurative 'armor' rather than showing remorse.
Engages in underhanded dealings, including paying to cover up illegal activities involving his associates.
Listens quietly to John Dean's explanation about Mafia-like activities, appearing deep in thought but remaining silent.
Listens quietly and thoughtfully to John Dean's explanation, showing a deep contemplative demeanor (hands cupped over mouth, frown)
Has a microphone secretly installed in his desk, indicating clandestine surveillance and preparation
Allows or is associated with covertly receiving questionable FBI reports and possible deception within his administration (John Dean receiving FBI reports secretly)
Discusses secretly obtaining a million dollars in cash for undisclosed purposes.
Dismisses concerns about the seriousness of the scandal, calling it 'penny-ante shit' and minimizing its impact.
Expresses worry about the consequences for people he cares about (e.g., Bob and others) being indicted.
Assesses funding needs and confidently asserts the ability to secure a million dollars in cash, showing awareness of resources and practical problem-solving.
Dismisses serious concerns about growing legal and ethical crises, minimizing their significance and ignoring warnings from close aides, potentially undermining effective crisis management.
Encourages a strategy of fighting the crisis aggressively and suppressing testimony, demonstrating a tactical yet morally questionable approach to problem-solving under pressure.
Puts arm around Dean's shoulder, offers a weekend retreat to Camp David.
Asks Dean to write a full report on Watergate, emphasizing trust and loyalty.
Promises Dean he won't let his people go to jail, expresses complete confidence.
Uses threats about consequences if Dean betrays loyalty.
Appears shaken and publicly claims commitment to truth.
Instructs John Dean to write a full report on Watergate, trying to control the investigation and limit exposure to others.
Appears shaken and ashen-faced on TV, struggling to maintain composure amidst crisis.
Tries to assert loyalty and protect his aides from jail, showing attempt at damage control.
Publicly accepts resignations of close associates, calls them finest public servants, emphasizes no whitewash and love for America, ending with blessings to the nation and individuals.
Dismisses aide Haldeman’s offer for more guidance with indifferent wave.
Sits alone in shadows, devastated after lights go off.
Responds with silence to Pat's attempts to communicate, shows icy stare and refuses to discuss feelings or issues.
Rejects Pat's attempt to engage and cuts himself off from others, refuses to ask for help despite obvious distress.
Refuses to engage in conversation or seek help despite obvious personal and political crisis, isolates himself from close advisors and family.
Firmly states he will not pardon a convicted Bob Haldeman, demonstrating decisiveness in a difficult moment.
Puts down his fork, embarrassed when confronted by Pat; says 'Thank you' after she stops trying to interfere.
Continues eating alone after Pat walks out, showing detachment from her pain.
Confesses embarrassment and puts down his fork when confronted by Pat about debts and costs, showing a moment of vulnerability but not defiance or skillful handling of criticism.
Returns to eating dinner calmly after confrontation and letting Pat leave, indicating detachment or avoidance rather than confident or skillful problem-solving.
Engages in a friendly meeting with Leonid Brezhnev through an interpreter, listens attentively.
Whispers privately with Haig, excusing himself from the conversation with Brezhnev.
Engages in a diplomatic meeting with Soviet leaders, maintains composure, and navigates sensitive geopolitical topics confidently.
Whispers privately with Haig during tense moments, indicating reliance on trusted advisors for counsel.
Does not respond impulsively to provocative or critical statements by Brezhnev regarding Mao and alliances, showing measured and strategic behavior.
Looks steadily at his daughter Julie and responds sincerely to her question about covering up.
Expresses hope that he hasn't let his daughter down.
Remains relatively silent and unresponsive towards broader pressures and accusations (no direct aggressive or conciliatory public behavior shown).
Looks steadily at his daughter Julie when asked if he covered it up, demonstrating composure under emotional pressure.
Is visibly shaken and appears as a man with little time left when confronted by Brezhnev, showing vulnerability and loss of confidence.
Sits alone in bed looking shell-shocked and terrified upon revelation of tapes, screams out for Pat in distress.
Records virtually every conversation without others' knowledge, including family.
Remains alone and sleepless in bed, visibly distressed and shell-shocked upon learning the tapes exist and the potential consequences.
Begins coughing up blood, panics, and calls out for Pat, showing vulnerability at a critical moment.
Pat shows concern and attends to Nixon closely in hospital; Nixon struggles physically but is surrounded by attentive staff.
Nixon’s internal vision focuses on family memories, suggesting private emotional connection to his roots.
No direct interaction with others or expressions of warmth are shown; mostly physical vulnerability and medical intervention.
Struggles to rise despite illness; gasps and attempts to overcome physical limitation.
Remains conscious and aware even under physical distress; presence of mind as respiratory support is fitted.
No direct action regarding political or legal crisis; passive while allegations and investigations advance.
Fiercely refuses to comply with subpoena, yells 'Never! Over my dead body!'
Calls subpoenaing lawyers 'Kennedy-loving Harvard Democrat cocksuckers'
Refuses to yield to pressure, asserts confidence in appointment of Supreme Court justices, shows defiance against impeachment threats.
Dismisses seriousness of impeachment charges, underestimates political risks, shows wounded surprise at lack of Senate support.
Dismisses the suffering of POWs and their families, shows bitterness and sarcasm about being 'compassionate' or 'proud' of them.
Refuses to show sympathy, focuses on firing Cox and others immediately despite the situation.
Glowers darkly and threatens retaliation rather than seeking reconciliation or understanding.
Refuses to resign despite pressure, asserts willingness to fight publicly and aggressively.
Demands firing of Cox and others rapidly and by any means, showing impulsiveness and disregard for proper procedures.
Ignores advice and concerns from aides such as Buzhardt and Haig about legal and political risks.
Urges Ziegler to not give in or admit defeat, invoking the endurance of POWs and emphasizing fighting rather than showing vulnerability.
Pat and Nixon share a moment of tension; Nixon tries to explain his actions to Pat but is evasive and drunk.
Refuses to share his private tapes even with his wife Pat and insists they belong to him alone.
Becomes turbulent and upset when confronted about his emotional isolation and secrecy.
Rejects communication or comfort from the imagined presence of his mother, showing emotional shutdown.
Refuses to let others see the tapes, asserting control over sensitive information.
Shows emotional turmoil and inner conflict, is evasive and denies confronting personal issues directly.
Clings to his private recordings as a form of control and self-protection rather than open communication.
Grows increasingly drunk while obsessively replaying tapes, showing isolation and self-preoccupation.
Shows visible distress and frustration when confronted with incriminating evidence, but does not engage others warmly.
Carefully listens and reviews tape recordings repeatedly, attempts to understand content amidst rising stress and intoxication.
Shows visible distress and loss of control (gets drunker), fails to prevent damage from missing critical tape segments.
Engages professional lawyers and advisors actively reviewing transcripts and legal issues.
Reacting aghast and frustrated at legal developments and evidence suspicions rather than strategically addressing situation.
Addresses the nation on TV, attempts to sincerely deny wrongdoing and reassure the public.
Insists on controlling public perception, showing prioritization of image over transparency.
Shows no visible signs of empathy toward family or staff affected by the crisis; Pat Nixon appears numb and isolated.
Gives a televised address attempting to explain and justify his actions regarding the Watergate scandal.
Maintains a defensive and disconnected stance despite clear evidence against him, showing a lack of realistic self-assessment as observed by close aides.
Attempts to assert his innocence decisively by stating 'I am not a crook' to the nation.
Sits alone in the White House at night, listening to loud music and staring glumly at a family photo album.
Refuses to comply with the Supreme Court ruling on executive privilege, attempting to withhold subpoenaed tapes.
Sits in isolation listening to loud music, reflecting on family portraits amid impeachment proceedings.
Dismisses concerns about incriminating evidence, insisting he was protecting national security.
Shows moment of silence and sighs after hearing the gravity of the situation.
Dismisses legal concerns about incriminating evidence, claiming national security justification and contesting context.
Engages in discussion involving potential use of the army and contemplating resignation, showing some awareness of stakes but unclear strategic direction.
Responds to advice with silence and resignation (sighs), appearing uncertain and possibly overwhelmed by legal and political pressures.
Interrupts Haig to deny knowledge about the tape gap.
Looks down blankly at resignation letter, showing resignation and possible vulnerability.
Expresses ironic bitterness toward Kissinger, indicating distrust and feeling of betrayal.
Expresses concern about how history will remember him and the shame of being called a crook.
Acknowledges Kissinger as his only friend and equal, showing vulnerability and appreciation.
Invites Kissinger to pray with him, revealing a moment of sincerity and seeking shared comfort.
Signs resignation paper reluctantly and with pause, showing internal conflict but no overt warmth.
Prays silently, sobs openly expressing deep emotional vulnerability and regret over the country's division and personal failures.
Displays self-pity and blames external hatred despite achievements, showing a degree of sincerity and emotional openness.
Resumes customary bluffness and bravado in face of defeat, exhibiting emotional guardedness and distancing from genuine warmth.
No aggressive or hostile actions present, keeps composed in difficult circumstances, suggesting tolerance in interactions.
Acknowledges the national suffering, compares himself to a sacrifice for the country.
Expresses cynicism about the press and loss of respect for institutions, portrays himself as a victim.
Appears vulnerable and weakened in front of Pat, allowing her to support him.
Allows Pat to comfort him when he is emotionally vulnerable and expresses fear.
Remembers his father positively as a hardworking, honorable man, acknowledging the value of every job.
Breaks down emotionally and admits fear and vulnerability.
Reflects on his father's hardworking but humble background and honors the value of doing one's job well.
Speaks sincerely about his mother’s suffering and loss, showing vulnerability and emotional restraint while comforting his staff who are weeping.
Quotes Theodore Roosevelt on grief and perseverance to inspire resilience and hope in others.
Holds himself together by sheer force of will in an emotional moment, reads from a well-leafed book publicly for the first time to inspire staff.
Connects personal tragedy to historical example of Theodore Roosevelt's resilience, framing setbacks as beginnings not endings.
Expresses a personal sense of kinship with every American and prays for God's grace upon leaving office.
In voiceover, advises to never be petty or discouraged, promotes peace by warning against hatred.
Raises arms in twin-V salute with a brave smile while leaving office.
Faces public departure from the presidency with brave composure and delivers thoughtful farewell messages encouraging resilience and peace.
Maintains that had he not been forced from office, major geopolitical events would have unfolded differently, showing continued confidence in his historical role.
After resignation, lives a productive elder statesman life writing books, traveling, and receiving honors from multiple presidents.
